data.title: [Tracker] v3.0 Particles issues
data.body:
### 3D/Multimesh:
- [x] 3D particles blink when set a velocity of 0 https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10183 (bug)
- [x] Particles don't fire again when unmarking "One Shot" https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10181 (bug/enhancement)
- [x] Emission shape "directed points" is unable to emit in negative directions https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10233 (bug)
- [ ] 3D particles emission gets chunky if framerate is slowed down  https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10186 (bug)
- [ ] 3D particles are extremely laggy when seen close https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10185 (bug)
- [ ] 3D particles cannot rotate https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10182 (bug)
- [ ] MultiMesh does not change color of instances #10217 (bug)
- [ ] MultiMesh rendering issues in grid like setup  #10253 (bug)
- [x]  Shape mode "points" and "directed points": impossible to move emission point in negative axis https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10236 (bug/enhancement)
- [ ] Particles 3D - gravity does not work if initial velocity iz zero #10349 (bug)
- [ ] Particles 3D initial velocity always random #10348 (bug)
- [ ] Ability to convert buildin shaders and spatial material to text #10242 (enhancement)
- [ ] Shape mode "points": points can be defined only in distance from 0 to 1 from the origin https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10235 (enhancement)
- [ ] color gradient / albedo of mesh is preferred over particle material https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/9781 (enhancement)
- [ ] Change particles to use emission rate rather than max allowed particles.  https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4294 (enhancement)
- [ ] Trail divisor is not very good https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10363 (enhancement)

### Couple less strict issues:
- [ ] Particle 3d issues #10234 (bug)
- [ ] Particle System Improvement  #6377 (feature proposal)
- [ ] Enhanced 2D and 3D particle system & tooling #4250 (feature proposal)

### 2D: 
- [ ] 2D particles are glitchy  https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/9884 (bug)
- [ ] Particle2D emitting settings create unexpected results. #4003 (bug)
- [ ] Observing fast moving Particles2D from a fast moving object causes visual glitch. #6373 (bug)
- [ ] Particles2d random initial velocity doesn't seem to do anything #10668 (bug)
- [ ]  emission_stopped signal for particles2d node  #10954 (enhancement)

data.title: Particles 3D, Shape mode "points" and "directed points": impossible to move emission point in negative axis
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
e93ce33 

**Issue description:**
With R/G/B color pixels we can code position of emission points with those emission shape modes: `points' and 'directed points`. I Haven't found any way to move emission point behind the spatial r/g/b can only be used to move in positive xyz axis. Some way to put those points in negative axis would be very helpful to position various effects in a proper way. Not sure how https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10235 will be resolved, but if we would have additional scaling factor then maybe positions range could be defined in color from -1 to 1 and multiples by position scaling factor.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Particles 3D, Shape mode "points": points can be defined only in distance from 0 to 1 from the origin
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
e93ce33 Gpu: Gtx1060

**Issue description:**
With R/G/B color pixels we can code position of emission points in `points' and 'directed points` emission shapes. But it's impossible to move them They can have position values only from 0 to 1 in local world coords. 
Take a look at the screen:
![part_pos](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/29184204-b37cea28-7e05-11e7-933d-923c493a9ac5.png)

Yellow box visibility is not very big (radius around 2 I think), lets say I have some bigger object in the game like boss and I wanted to use one particle emitter to have some nice effect. Unfortunately distance from the center cant be more than 1 (but only in positive directions). 
Maybe we could have additional factor to scale this distance?

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Particles 3D: emission shape "directed points" is unable to emit in negative directions
data.body:
*bugsquad edit:* it seems it's working, we just need assign negative float numbers to the texture (as a channel values). So it seems this issue will be more about documenting work-flow for this.

-----------

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
e93ce339dcdf4e9ade63286cfa04cdd4b5a8ecd4

**Issue description:**
This issue is about EmissionShape `directed points` mode
I haven't found any way to emit particles in negative axis direction. We can define with r/g/b channel direction vector in which given particle should be emitted (x/y/z), but there is no way to tell particle emitter to reverse axis (maybe some info in A channel? or 0 = reverse, 256 = positive). 
Don't know, maybe it's possible somehow, but unfortunatelly without those I'm considering this functionallity not really usable for many scenarios. For example its impossible to create such effect like this one with this mode:
![center_particles](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/29183142-e08735fe-7e01-11e7-9696-5b7b641c0cc5.gif)


**Steps to reproduce:**


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Particles 3D: emission shape "directed points" is broken
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
e93ce339dcdf4e9ade63286cfa04cdd4b5a8ecd4 Gpu: Gtx1060

**Issue description:**
EmissionShape `directed points` inside particles process material don't seems to behave correctly. I have set number of particles points to 3 and this texture as an input for positions as well as directions: 
![input](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/29181656-42f15ee6-7dfc-11e7-9702-09d40012fdda.png)
Result:
![directedparticles](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/29181699-693d8b38-7dfc-11e7-9ff1-c96330372179.gif)

There are two problems:
1. One of the emitters is emitting very short living particles (~=1 frame)
2. This is visible the most in EmissionShape `points` (the more without normal texture). Emission is very unbalanced/unregular. Sometimes one from emission points is not emitting anything for second or half while other is emitting more particles

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open sample project.
2. Open res://Tests/Particles/DirectedParticles.tscn scene

**Link to minimal example project:**
[IssueDirectedParticle.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1215723/IssueDirectedParticle.zip)

data.title: Port StreamPeerBuffer to 2.1
data.body: `StreamPeerBuffer` is indispensable for custom network protocols in Godot because it provides an easy way to build up / break down a byte array from / to different Godot types. I think it should be ported to 2.1 because currently 2.1's `PacketPeer`'s `put_packet` and `get_packet` methods are close to useless since there is nothing like `StreamPeerBuffer` to manipulate the packets.

data.title: AnimationPlayer.seek() causes animation to get stuck
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 16.04
godot 2.1.3-stable
godot 2.1.4-beta_20170731

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
AnimationPlayer.seek() to the exact start or end time of an animation causes it to get stuck. Meaning if for example opacity is set to 0 at that time, the animation keeps setting opacity to 0, and can't be changed unless the AnimationPlayer is manually stopped or given another animation to play.
```
animation_player.play("anim")
animation_player.seek(animation_player.get_current_animation_length(), true/false)
```
or
```
animation_player.play_backwards("anim")
animation_player.seek(0, true/false)
```


**Steps to reproduce:**

1. Create an AnimationPlayer
2. Create a simple animation that animates a property
3. Create a script that starts the animation and then seek to 0 or the animation length
4. Try and modify the same property from the Remote Inspector and observe as it changes back

If you seek to 0.1 second instead of 0 or to animation length - 0.1 instead of animation length, it stops the AnimationPlayer correctly.

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Unhandled Exception when changing audio devices while device-specific Windows spatial audio filters are active.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win10x64pro v1703 b15063.540 w/Asus Sabertooth x79 using Realtek ALC892 audio chipset, Windows spatial sound filters active. Godot v3.0 alpha 1536cc4

**Issue description:**
I executed Godot, then while it was idle on the project selection interface, I plugged in my headphones. On my system (Win10x64pro v1703 b15063.540 w/Asus Sabertooth x79 using Realtek ALC892 audio chipset) my headphone jack in the front disables the rear speaker and makes the headphones (considered another device) the primary Windows audio output device. When this occurred, Godot crashed. This did not happen when I tried to simulate it by changing my audio device in the Windows audio device manager with a new instance of Godot loaded to the same state. The crash also did not occur when I unplugged my headphones, only when plugging them in. This led me to suspect the problem is not with changing devices. I realized I was using the Dolby Atmos audio filter with 7.1 virtual surround enabled (Windows 10 spatial audio), which is configured only for use with my... *headphones*. When I right-clicked my audio TSA icon and hit the menu option for Atmos, I found it had silently crashed, and Windows had now detected it, offering to reenable the application. I then disabled Atmos, and all filters. I ran Godot and repeatedly plugged/unplugged the jack. Everything was fine. I activated another filter, Windows Sonic for Headphones, again with virtual surround on. Again Godot crashes on device change. Disabling the virtual surround had no effect, still crashes. Also tested with the editor in other states, like with a project loaded, same result as expected. Opening the editor and toggling the effect on my headphone device settings while they are active causes no error.

MSVS2015 JIT debugger reports an unhandled win32 exception at 0x0007FFF6EF9A7CA5

Breaking execution at the exception puts me on the last brace of RtApi :: error. errorText_ reads "RtApiDs::callbackEvent: error (Buffer lost) getting current write position!"

**Conclusion**
Changing audio devices while Windows spatial sound filters are enabled causes an unhandled exception due to the output stream buffer being lost. But why is this a problem only when using spatial audio with device changes, not software changes? Is this actually a Windows bug to work around? I'm not sure how to best handle this, so I leave the code to others this time.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Enable spatial audio filters in Win10CE. With Godot loaded, plug/unplug headphone jack on an audio chipset with jack detection and retasking causing the filter to become enabled/disabled by the device change notification.

data.title: Mipmap related rendering glitches in 3.0 alpha 1
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win 7 x64 
Godot 3.0 alpha 1

**Issue description:**
Pictures are worth more than a thousand words.

![godot_v3 0-alpha1_win64_2017-08-10_11-20-19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4525388/29164121-ca682ca8-7dbe-11e7-8830-d9776fe5fef6.png)

The only practical difference between the left and right road is the size. Both roads are made of a sequence of quads using the same material. See how one road shows the middle markings (at this zoom level) and the other doesn't. If I zoomed in more, the other one would start showing too.

(The ground is a single quad too, but the bug isn't noticeable on it probably due to its size)

![godot_v3 0-alpha1_win64_2017-08-10_11-19-27](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4525388/29164189-f2358b36-7dbe-11e7-80a2-e6567581bc64.jpg)

Same scene, now angled. See how all the middle markings disappear giving way to a uniform black?

A gfycat because you can see how the angle affects the markings (both middle and side) disappearing.
https://gfycat.com/gifs/detail/YellowOldGalapagosdove

The final angles are extremely close to the angle my in-game camera uses.

The issue is present both in editor and in game.

**Steps to reproduce:**

slap a texture with some detail on a mostly uniform background on a quad, zoom and angle camera

**Link to minimal example project:**
If a minimal example is really needed, I believe I could whip one up today or tomorrow.

data.title: Metallic PBR is broken with ambient environment lighting
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win 10 Godot 3 current build

**Issue description:**
When environment>ambient light>sky contribution is at 0, materials behave as you would expect. In the first image, the sphere on the left is full metallic(1) with a roughness of 0.2. The sphere on the right is a dielectric material (metallic = 0) with roughness of 0.2.

The image looks as you would expect, with the rough metal sphere on the left receiving reflections from the environment, and no need for any ambient lighting from the environment HDR. The dielectric sphere on the right has some reflections but since there is no lighting in the scene(ambient or lights) it looks black. All is good!

![sky_contrib1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29156499-97deef98-7de5-11e7-935b-3089afd9f157.jpg)

In this next image, the environment>ambient light>sky contribution is set to 1 (which it should be as the new default). The dielectric material on the right is as you would expect, since it is now receiving ambient light from the HDR. However, the metallic sphere on the left is now looking very incorrect, even though the material has not changed since the first image.

It should look the same as it did in the first image, but for some reason the environment ambient light is effecting it(It is fully metallic/reflective so shouldn't be effected by ambient light). It looks like it is multiplying the ambient value over the reflection. This also occurs when a procedural sky is used instead of the HDR. 

![sky_contrib2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29156664-6cd96098-7de6-11e7-931b-2d9ba052c64e.jpg)


**Steps to reproduce:**

-change environment>ambient light>sky contribution to 1 with a sky(hdr or procedural)
-add a mesh with a full metallic material


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[broken_metallic.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1213783/broken_metallic.zip)

data.title: Audio Mixer Usability Improvement
data.body:
This is a suggestion for AudioMixer UI improvement.

Right now the mixer is like this.
![audio_bus_layout](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/434987/29155630-f71099e2-7dba-11e7-83ff-d88a5de5a5fc.png)

On a first glance, there are several buttons on the top which don't make a good sense of what they will do.
Of course, after playing with those for some time the developer will realize what they do and be ok with it. However, I propose a new interface which is as shown below.

1. Remove all those not-so-informatory buttons on the top.
![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/434987/29155731-81ca41f0-7dbb-11e7-9db7-ec9198ac3ce6.png)
Why?
Load, Save As, Default, Create. These button functions can be invoked by several actions from the developer who is used to Godot interface.
![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/434987/29155823-f66e5d16-7dbb-11e7-8a34-2b14cd9f4c57.png)

Load - Double click on an Audio Bus resource in the File browser
Save As - Use the Save button in the Resource's Inspector
Default - Not needed because the developer can create a default bus and double click on that to open it.
Create - Use the New Resource button in the Inspector
(If problems with Resource-Save for Audio Bus Layout, then a bug report is required to fix that before this)

2. Add Bus buttons should be like a big button to the right side, like this.
![3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/434987/29155890-60a0fb44-7dbc-11e7-9519-584c90873023.png)
c1. Bus name editing text focus and defocus should be distinguishable.
c2. Add a 3-dot button and use this for a popup menu
c3. The popup menu should contain Duplicate and Delete buttons. Right-clicking on a bus is not user-friendly because the bus does not look like it has a right click menu.
c4. The big Add bus button

data.title: Incorrect positioning of axes and standard grid lines in 3D scenes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Debian Buster/Testing 64 bits up-to-date
Godot versions < 3 (not present on v3 alpha)
CPU: Intel i5 4210u
GPU: Intel HD 4400 (Haswell) (i915 kernel driver)

Present in both the official release and the compiled version of branch 2.1

Compiled with `scons platform=x11 builtin_openssl=yes`

**Issue description:**
When an empty 3D scene is created, some lines in the grid of the XZ plane are positioned incorrectly, as are the lines representing the axes. The following pictures speak for themselves:

![captura de tela de 2017-08-10 01-46-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4951094/29155066-b1d913fe-7d6f-11e7-80cd-7f4856da4d81.png)
![captura de tela de 2017-08-10 01-46-46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4951094/29155067-b1da4a9e-7d6f-11e7-9117-970a059a5514.png)

The bug may have been due to some update of the video module, because a few months ago it did not happen. However, I believe it is important because in v3 alpha it is not present.

**Steps to reproduce:**
* Open an 3D view on an empty scene (actually I haven't tested with non-empty 3D scenes because I usually do not make 3D projects)

data.title: Some default signal parameters conflict with member variables
data.body:
**Ubuntu 17.04 - Godot version: e8192d4**


**Issue description:**
For example: The default parameter name "pressed" in the "toggled()" signal conflicts with the member variable "pressed" in Button nodes, and the parameter "text" in "text_changed()" conflicts with the variable "text" in both LineEdit and Button nodes.

data.title: An example of ancestor constructor usage in documentation
data.body:
**bugsquad edit:** The issue was not real, but the documentation might be little misleading. Current docs example looks like this: 
```
func _init(args).(parent_args):
   pass
```
And basically that's what @CowThing was trying to do. Instead example in docs should look more like this I think:
```
func _init(args, parent_args).(parent_args):
   pass
```

-------

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - Godot 2.1.4 and Godot 3.0 alpha 1

**Issue description:**
If I have a base class that has arguments, and another class with arguments extends it, I get the following error:
`Parser Error: Identifier not found: a` on line 11 of the following script, which is `func _init(b).(a):`

In the [documentation on classes](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/learning/scripting/gdscript/gdscript_basics.html#class-constructor) it mentions that parent arguments are passed like this:
```
func _init(args).(parent_args):
   pass
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
Add this script to a Node and run the project
```GDScript
extends Node

func _ready():
	var x = TestClass.new("A", "B")

class TestBase:
	func _init(a):
		print("a: ", a)

class TestClass extends TestBase:
	func _init(b).(a):
		print("b: ", b)
```

data.title: Actions not working on exported game on Godot-master and Godot-3.0-alpha1
data.body:
## Version
Godot 3.0-alpha1 and master on Windows 10 Desktop

## Issue
After exporting a project from Godot 3.0 master or alpha 1, actions are not being recognized

## Suspected cause
Binary is not able to read actions from project.binary.  Once you throw the project.godot file in the same directory, it works.
